https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#

The USACE Safety of Dams Policies and Procedures (Engineeering Report 1110-2-1156) defines various acronyms and terms commonly used in this regulation to describe phases, types, and parts of cost products. These terms are defined in the glossary section of the regulation.

Ontology documentation automatically generated by Ontospy on Tue, 16 Jul 2024 13:37:52

 Table of Content

  • A-Z of Terms
  • SKOS Concepts

https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#

The USACE Safety of Dams Policies and Procedures (Engineeering Report 1110-2-1156) defines various acronyms and terms commonly used in this regulation to describe phases, types, and parts of cost products. These terms are defined in the glossary section of the regulation.

dcterms:description

The USACE Safety of Dams Policies and Procedures (Engineeering Report 1110-2-1156) defines various acronyms and terms commonly used in this regulation to describe phases, types, and parts of cost products. These terms are defined in the glossary section of the regulation.

 SKOS Concepts

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:ATR_Team   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:ATR_Team

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:ATR_Team is a leaf node.

Description

For dam safety studies, the ATR team must include members from and be coordinated with the RMC as well as recognized experts (internal and external to USACE) in the field of risk assessment. The ATR team findings will be vetted with the MSC DSO, Risk Management Center, and HQUSACE.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:ATR_Team a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "ATR Team" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=487" ;

skos:definition "For dam safety studies, the ATR team must include members from and be coordinated with the RMC as well as recognized experts (internal and external to USACE) in the field of risk assessment. The ATR team findings will be vetted with the MSC DSO, Risk Management Center, and HQUSACE." ;

skos:prefLabel "ATR Team" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Abutment   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Abutment

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Abutment is a leaf node.

Description

That part of the valley side against which the dam is constructed. An artificial abutment is sometimes constructed as a concrete gravity section to take the thrust of an arch dam where there is no suitable natural abutment. The left and right abutments of dams are defined with the observer viewing the dam looking in the downstream direction, unless otherwise indicated.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Abutment a wov:GlossaryTerm,

The left and right abutments of dams are defined with the observer viewing the dam looking in the downstream direction, unless otherwise indicated." ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Acceptable_Risk   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Acceptable_Risk

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Acceptable_Risk is a leaf node.

Description

A risk, for the purposes of life or work, everyone who might be impacted is prepared to accept assuming no changes in risk control mechanisms. Such risk is regarded as insignificant and adequately controlled. Action to further reduce such risk is usually not required.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Acceptable_Risk a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Acceptable Risk" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=487" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Acceptable Risk]" ;
skos:definition "A risk, for the purposes of life or work, everyone who might be impacted is prepared to accept assuming no changes in risk control mechanisms. Such risk is regarded as insignificant and adequately controlled. Action to further reduce such risk is usually not required." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Acceptable Risk" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Acre-foot   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Acre-foot

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Acre-foot is a leaf node.

Description

A unit of volumetric measure that would cover 1 acre to a depth of 1 foot. It is equal to 43,560 cubic feet. This is approximately 325,851.4 U.S. gallons.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Acre-foot a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Acre-foot" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=487" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Acre-foot]" ;
skos:definition "A unit of volumetric measure that would cover 1 acre to a depth of 1 foot. It is equal to 43,560 cubic feet. This is approximately 325,851.4 U.S. gallons." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Acre-foot" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Active_storage   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Active_storage

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Active_storage is a leaf node.

Description

The volume of the reservoir that is available for some use such as power generation, irrigation, flood control, or water supply. The bottom elevation is the minimum operating level.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Active_storage a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Active storage" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=523" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Active storage]" ;
skos:definition "The volume of the reservoir that is available for some use such as power generation, irrigation, flood control, or water supply. The bottom elevation is the minimum operating level." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Active storage" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Adit   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Adit

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Adit is a leaf node.

Description

A nearly horizontal underground excavation in an abutment having an opening in only one end, such as an opening in the face of a dam for access to galleries or operating chambers.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Adit]" ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Adverse_Consequences   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Adverse_Consequences

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Adverse_Consequences is a leaf node.

Description

The outcome of the failure of a dam or its appurtenances, including immediate, short and long-term, direct and indirect losses and effects. Loss may include human casualties, project benefits, monetary and economic damages, and environmental impact (Adapted from USACE).

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Adverse_Consequences a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Adverse Consequences" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=487" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Adverse Consequences]" ;
skos:definition "The outcome of the failure of a dam or its appurtenances, including immediate, short and long-term, direct and indirect losses and effects. Loss may include human casualties, project benefits, monetary and economic damages, and environmental impact (Adapted from USACE)." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Adverse Consequences" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Agency_Technical_Review_%28ATR%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Agency_Technical_Review_%28ATR%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Agency_Technical_Review_%28ATR%29 is a leaf node.

Description

An independent in-depth review designed to ensure the proper application of clearly established criteria, regulations, laws, codes, principles and professional practices. The ATR team reviews the various work products and assures that all the parts fit together in a coherent whole.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Agency_Technical_Review_%28ATR%29 a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Agency Technical Review (ATR)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=487" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Agency Technical Review (ATR)]" ;
skos:altLabel "ATR" ;
skos:definition "An independent in-depth review designed to ensure the proper application of clearly established criteria, regulations, laws, codes, principles and professional practices. The ATR team reviews the various work products and assures that all the parts fit together in a coherent whole." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Agency Technical Review (ATR)" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Annual_Inspections   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Annual_Inspections

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Annual_Inspections is a leaf node.

Description

Inspections conducted annually by the Operating Project staff with technical experts from Engineering or Operations (reference ER 1130-2-500 (reference A.60)). The goal is to monitor the performance of the dam and note any evidence of changes in performance or needed dam safety related maintenance. Findings must be documented and reviewed in support of Periodic Inspections (PI's) and Periodic Assessments (PA's).

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Annual_Inspections a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Annual Inspections" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=487" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Annual Inspections]" ;
skos:definition "Inspections conducted annually by the Operating Project staff with technical experts from Engineering or Operations (reference ER 1130-2-500 (reference A.60)). The goal is to monitor the performance of the dam and note any evidence of changes in performance or needed dam safety related maintenance. Findings must be documented and reviewed in support of Periodic Inspections (PI's) and Periodic Assessments (PA's)." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Annual Inspections" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Annual_Probability_of_Failure_%28APF%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Annual_Probability_of_Failure_%28APF%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Annual_Probability_of_Failure_%28APF%29 is a leaf node.

Description

For dams the combined estimated annual probability of failure from all failure modes associated with all loading or initiating event types that result in an unintentional release of the reservoir.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Annual_Probability_of_Failure_%28APF%29 a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Annual Probability of Failure (APF)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=487" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Annual Probability of Failure (APF)]" ;
skos:altLabel "APF" ;
skos:definition "For dams the combined estimated annual probability of failure from all failure modes associated with all loading or initiating event types that result in an unintentional release of the reservoir." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Annual Probability of Failure (APF)" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:As-Low-As-Reasonably-Practicable_%28ALARP%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:As-Low-As-Reasonably-Practicable_%28ALARP%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:As-Low-As-Reasonably-Practicable_%28ALARP%29 is a leaf node.

Description

That principle which states that risks, lower than the limit of tolerability, are tolerable only if risk reduction is impracticable or if the next increment of risk reduction is not cost effective compared to the improvement gained.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:As-Low-As-Reasonably-Practicable_%28ALARP%29 a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "As-Low-As-Reasonably-Practicable (ALARP)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=488" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[As-Low-As-Reasonably-Practicable (ALARP)]" ;
skos:altLabel "ALARP" ;
skos:definition "That principle which states that risks, lower than the limit of tolerability, are tolerable only if risk reduction is impracticable or if the next increment of risk reduction is not cost effective compared to the improvement gained." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "As-Low-As-Reasonably-Practicable (ALARP)" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Automatically_Operated_System   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Automatically_Operated_System

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Automatically_Operated_System is a leaf node.

Description

An automatically operated system is where operation is determined by automated means based on instrumentation data without requiring direct input from personnel.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Automatically Operated System]" ;
skos:definition "An automatically operated system is where operation is determined by automated means based on instrumentation data without requiring direct input from personnel." ;

skos:prefLabel "Automatically Operated System" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Average_Annual_Life_Lost_%28AALL%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Average_Annual_Life_Lost_%28AALL%29 is a leaf node.

Description

As used in the f-N plot, the expected value (average) of potential life loss of the probability distribution of potential life loss from dam failure.

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Axis_of_dam   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Axis_of_dam

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Axis_of_dam is a leaf node.

Description

The vertical plane or curved surface, chosen by a designer, which appears as a line, in plan, or in cross-section, from which the horizontal dimensions of the dam are referenced.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Axis of dam]" ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Baffle_block   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Baffle_block

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Baffle_block is a leaf node.

Description

A block, usually of concrete, constructed in a channel or stilling basin to dissipate the energy of water flowing at high velocity.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Base_thickness   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Base_thickness

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Base_thickness is a leaf node.

Description

Also referred to as base width. The maximum thickness or width of the dam measured horizontally between upstream and downstream faces and normal to the axis of the dam, but excluding projections for outlets, or other appurtenant structures.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Base_thickness a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Base thickness" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=488" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Base thickness]" ;
skos:definition "Also referred to as base width. The maximum thickness or width of the dam measured horizontally between upstream and downstream faces and normal to the axis of the dam, but excluding projections for outlets, or other appurtenant structures." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Base thickness" .

skos:definition "Angle of inclination from the vertical." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Batter" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Bedrock   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Bedrock

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Bedrock is a leaf node.

Description

The consolidated body of natural solid mineral matter which underlies the overburden soils.

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Breach   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Breach

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Breach is a leaf node.

Description

An opening through a dam that allows the uncontrolled draining of a reservoir. A controlled breach is a constructed opening. An uncontrolled breach is an unintentional opening caused by discharge from the reservoir. A breach is generally associated with the partial or total failure of the dam.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Breach a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Breach" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=488" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Breach]" ;
skos:definition "An opening through a dam that allows the uncontrolled draining of a reservoir. A controlled breach is a constructed opening. An uncontrolled breach is an unintentional opening caused by discharge from the reservoir. A breach is generally associated with the partial or total failure of the dam." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Breach" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Broadly_Acceptable_Risk   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Broadly_Acceptable_Risk

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Broadly_Acceptable_Risk is a leaf node.

Description

"Risks falling into this region are generally regarded as insignificant and adequately controlled. The levels of risk characterizing this region are comparable to those that people regard as insignificant or trivial in their daily lives. They are typical of the risk from activities that are inherently not very hazardous or from hazardous activities that can be, and are, readily controlled to produce very low risks" (HSE, 2001 reference A.145). By the nature of the hazard that dams pose it is inappropriate to attempt to manage them as a broadly acceptable risk and therefore the concept of the broadly acceptable risk level or limit does not apply to dams.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Broadly_Acceptable_Risk a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Broadly Acceptable Risk" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=488" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Broadly Acceptable Risk]" ;
skos:definition "\"Risks falling into this region are generally regarded as insignificant and adequately controlled. The levels of risk characterizing this region are comparable to those that people regard as insignificant or trivial in their daily lives. They are typical of the risk from activities that are inherently not very hazardous or from hazardous activities that can be, and are, readily controlled to produce very low risks\" (HSE, 2001 reference A.145). By the nature of the hazard that dams pose it is inappropriate to attempt to manage them as a broadly acceptable risk and therefore the concept of the broadly acceptable risk level or limit does not apply to dams." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Broadly Acceptable Risk" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Bulkhead_gate   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Bulkhead_gate

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Bulkhead_gate is a leaf node.

Description

A gate used either for temporary closure of a channel or conduit before dewatering it for inspection or maintenance or for closure against flowing water when the head difference is small, e.g., for diversion tunnel closure.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Bulkhead_gate a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Bulkhead gate" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=506" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Bulkhead gate]" ;
skos:definition "A gate used either for temporary closure of a channel or conduit before dewatering it for inspection or maintenance or for closure against flowing water when the head difference is small, e.g., for diversion tunnel closure." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Bulkhead gate" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Caretaker_Status   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Caretaker_Status

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Caretaker_Status is a leaf node.

Description

Real or personal property at a project site, in part or in whole, which currently is not utilized or occupied for current program authorized purposes. This may also include property that is "Inactive" (Not currently being used but may have a future need) or "Excess" (Formally identified as having no further program use including pending disposition actions). This does not include property placed in Mothball status. Caretaker status is defined at the project or project site level, not the feature level."

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Caretaker_Status a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Caretaker Status" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=489" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Caretaker Status]" ;
skos:definition "Real or personal property at a project site, in part or in whole, which currently is not utilized or occupied for current program authorized purposes. This may also include property that is \"Inactive\" (Not currently being used but may have a future need) or \"Excess\" (Formally identified as having no further program use including pending disposition actions). This does not include property placed in Mothball status. Caretaker status is defined at the project or project site level, not the feature level.\"" ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Caretaker Status" .

A sudden and great disaster causing misfortune, destruction, or irreplaceable loss extensive enough to cripple activities in an area.

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Cofferdam   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Cofferdam

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Cofferdam is a leaf node.

Description

A temporary structure enclosing all or part of the construction area so that construction can proceed in the dry. A diversion cofferdam diverts a river into a pipe, channel, or tunnel.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Conduit   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Conduit

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Conduit is a leaf node.

Description

A closed channel to convey water through, around, or under a dam.

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

skos:definition "A closed channel to convey water through, around, or under a dam." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Conduit" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Confirmed_%28Unconfirmed%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Confirmed_%28Unconfirmed%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Confirmed_%28Unconfirmed%29 is a leaf node.

Description

Through investigation or other means, Dam Safety issue is firmly established as of concern or not. Unconfirmed “ not confirmed.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Confirmed_Dam_Safety_Issues   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Confirmed_Dam_Safety_Issues

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Confirmed_Dam_Safety_Issues is a leaf node.

Description

Manifested or obvious issues are those impacting the safe operation of a dam. Examples of confirmed issues can be described as performance concerns - lack of spillway or seismic capacity, or deficiencies that are demonstrated by signs of seepage and boils, obvious flaws or defects, component distress or malfunction, unusual settlement, unsatisfactory instrument readings, etc. that can be specifically linked to one or more potential failure modes.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Confirmed_Dam_Safety_Issues a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Confirmed Dam Safety Issues" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=490" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Confirmed Dam Safety Issues]" ;
skos:definition "Manifested or obvious issues are those impacting the safe operation of a dam. Examples of confirmed issues can be described as performance concerns - lack of spillway or seismic capacity, or deficiencies that are demonstrated by signs of seepage and boils, obvious flaws or defects, component distress or malfunction, unusual settlement, unsatisfactory instrument readings, etc. that can be specifically linked to one or more potential failure modes." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Confirmed Dam Safety Issues" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Constructability_evaluation_%28CE%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Constructability_evaluation_%28CE%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Constructability_evaluation_%28CE%29 is a leaf node.

Description

A project review that concentrates on schedule, cost, constructability, and risks that may be inherent to the construction of a project. This review is performed and documented by a team designated by the DSMMCX/DSPC. A CE report is prepared, briefed to the project PDT and approved by the DSPC. A CE will be performed at least during the steps of evaluation and comparison of alternatives in the plan formulation process and during PED prior to final design.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Constructability_evaluation_%28CE%29 a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Constructability evaluation (CE)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=490" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Constructability evaluation (CE)]" ;
skos:altLabel "CE" ;
skos:definition "A project review that concentrates on schedule, cost, constructability, and risks that may be inherent to the construction of a project. This review is performed and documented by a team designated by the DSMMCX/DSPC. A CE report is prepared, briefed to the project PDT and approved by the DSPC. A CE will be performed at least during the steps of evaluation and comparison of alternatives in the plan formulation process and during PED prior to final design." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Contact_Grouting   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Contact_Grouting

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Contact_Grouting is a leaf node.

Description

Filling, with cement grout, any voids existing at the contact of two zones of different materials, e.g., between a concrete tunnel lining and the surrounding rock.

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Core   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Core

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Core is a leaf node.

Description

A zone of low permeability material in an embankment dam. The core is sometimes referred to as central core, inclined core, puddle clay core, rolled clay core, or impervious zone.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Core a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Core" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=490" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Core]" ;
skos:definition "A zone of low permeability material in an embankment dam. The core is sometimes referred to as central core, inclined core, puddle clay core, rolled clay core, or impervious zone." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Core" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Core_Wall   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Core_Wall

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Core_Wall is a leaf node.

Description

A wall built of relatively impervious material, usually of concrete or asphaltic concrete, in the body of an embankment dam to prevent seepage.

CSSL is the ratio of the cost of a proposed risk reduction measure divided by the consequent estimate of 'Statistical Lives Saved'.

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Credible_Existing_and_Future_Without_Federal_Action_Risk_Estimate   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Credible_Existing_and_Future_Without_Federal_Action_Risk_Estimate

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Credible_Existing_and_Future_Without_Federal_Action_Risk_Estimate is a leaf node.

Description

Occurs when the conditional load response probabilities and consequences used to estimate the residual project risk (incremental and non-breach) are supported by sufficient data, analysis, and performance history. The need for additional information, studies, and investigations to determine or resolve uncertainty should be determined after parametric studies are completed and insight is gained as to improvement in the confidence of the risk estimate by more accurately predicting conditional load response probabilities or life loss estimates. Typically, risk estimates for confirmed issues can be established with existing data and performance history because the physical manifestations are visual and measurable. Unconfirmed issues may require the collection of additional data if the concerns are less obvious or cannot be linked to a specific failure mode or observation. Credible Failure Mode “ A physically plausible failure mode.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Credible_Existing_and_Future_Without_Federal_Action_Risk_Estimate a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Credible Existing and Future Without Federal Action Risk Estimate" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=490" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Credible Existing and Future Without Federal Action Risk Estimate]" ;
skos:definition "Occurs when the conditional load response probabilities and consequences used to estimate the residual project risk (incremental and non-breach) are supported by sufficient data, analysis, and performance history. The need for additional information, studies, and investigations to determine or resolve uncertainty should be determined after parametric studies are completed and insight is gained as to improvement in the confidence of the risk estimate by more accurately predicting conditional load response probabilities or life loss estimates. Typically, risk estimates for confirmed issues can be established with existing data and performance history because the physical manifestations are visual and measurable. Unconfirmed issues may require the collection of additional data if the concerns are less obvious or cannot be linked to a specific failure mode or observation. Credible Failure Mode “ A physically plausible failure mode." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Credible Existing and Future Without Federal Action Risk Estimate" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Critical_feature   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Critical_feature

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Critical_feature is a leaf node.

Description

For Seismic Evaluation “ Critical features are the engineered structures, natural site conditions, or operating equipment and utilities at high hazard projects whose failure during or immediately following an earthquake could result in loss of life.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Critical feature]" ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Critically_near_failure   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Critically_near_failure

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Critically_near_failure is a leaf node.

Description

Failure sequence has been initiated and continues under normal loading. Without intervention (e.g., interim risk reduction measures or remediation), dam is expected to fail.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Critically_near_failure a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Critically near failure" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=491" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Critically near failure]" ;
skos:definition "Failure sequence has been initiated and continues under normal loading. Without intervention (e.g., interim risk reduction measures or remediation), dam is expected to fail." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Critically near failure" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Cross_section   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Cross_section

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Cross_section is a leaf node.

Description

An elevation view of a dam formed by passing a plane through the dam perpendicular to the axis.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Cross section" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=491" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Cross section]" ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Cutoff_trench   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Cutoff_trench

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Cutoff_trench is a leaf node.

Description

A foundation excavation later to be filled with impervious material so as to limit seepage beneath a dam.

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Cutoff_wall   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Cutoff_wall

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Cutoff_wall is a leaf node.

Description

A wall of impervious material usually of concrete, asphaltic concrete, or steel sheet piling constructed in the foundation and abutments to reduce seepage beneath and adjacent to the dam.

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_1_%28Very_High_Urgency%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_1_%28Very_High_Urgency%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_1_%28Very_High_Urgency%29 is a leaf node.

Description

Dams where progression toward failure is confirmed to be taking place under normal operations and the dam is almost certain to fail under normal operations within a few years without intervention; or the incremental risk “ combination of life or economic consequences with likelihood of failure “ is very high. USACE considers this level of life-risk to be unacceptable except in extraordinary circumstances.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_1_%28Very_High_Urgency%29 a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "DSAC 1 (Very High Urgency)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=498" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[DSAC 1 (Very High Urgency)]" ;
skos:definition "Dams where progression toward failure is confirmed to be taking place under normal operations and the dam is almost certain to fail under normal operations within a few years without intervention; or the incremental risk “ combination of life or economic consequences with likelihood of failure “ is very high. USACE considers this level of life-risk to be unacceptable except in extraordinary circumstances." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "DSAC 1 (Very High Urgency)" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_2_%28High_Urgency%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_2_%28High_Urgency%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_2_%28High_Urgency%29 is a leaf node.

Description

Dams where failure could begin during normal operations or be initiated by an event. The likelihood of failure from one of these occurrences, prior to remediation, is too high to assure public safety; or the incremental risk “ combination of life or economic consequences with likelihood of failure “ is high. USACE considers this level of life-risk to be unacceptable except in extraordinary circumstances.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_2_%28High_Urgency%29 a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "DSAC 2 (High Urgency)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=498" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[DSAC 2 (High Urgency)]" ;
skos:definition "Dams where failure could begin during normal operations or be initiated by an event. The likelihood of failure from one of these occurrences, prior to remediation, is too high to assure public safety; or the incremental risk “ combination of life or economic consequences with likelihood of failure “ is high. USACE considers this level of life-risk to be unacceptable except in extraordinary circumstances." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "DSAC 2 (High Urgency)" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_3_%28Moderate_Urgency%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_3_%28Moderate_Urgency%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_3_%28Moderate_Urgency%29 is a leaf node.

Description

Dams in this class have issues where the incremental risk “ combination life, economic, or environmental consequences with likelihood of failure “ is moderate. USACE considers this level of life-risk to be unacceptable except in unusual circumstances.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_4_%28Low_Urgency%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_4_%28Low_Urgency%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_4_%28Low_Urgency%29 is a leaf node.

Description

Dams are inadequate with low incremental risk such that the incremental risk “ combination of life, economic, or environmental consequences with a likelihood of failure “ is low and the dam may not meet all essential USACE guidelines. USACE considers this level of life-risk to be in the range of tolerability but the dam does not meet all essential USACE guidelines.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_4_%28Low_Urgency%29 a wov:GlossaryTerm,

USACE considers this level of life-risk to be in the range of tolerability but the dam does not meet all essential USACE guidelines." ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_5_%28Normal%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_5_%28Normal%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:DSAC_5_%28Normal%29 is a leaf node.

Description

Dams in this class are where the incremental risk - combination life, economic, or environmental consequences with likelihood of failure “ is very low and the dam meets all essential USACE guidelines (see Appendix F). USACE considers this Level of life-safety risk to be tolerable.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=498" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[DSAC 5 (Normal)]" ;

USACE considers this Level of life-safety risk to be tolerable." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam is a leaf node.

Description

An artificial barrier, including appurtenant works, constructed for the purpose of storage, control, or diversion of water, and which (1) is twenty-five feet or more in height from the natural bed of the stream or watercourse measured at the downstream toe of the barrier or from the lowest elevation of the outside limit of the barrier if it is not across a stream channel or watercourse, to the maximum water storage elevation or (2) has an impounding capacity at maximum water storage elevation of fifty acre-feet or more. Any such barrier which is under six feet in height regardless of storage capacity, or which has a storage capacity at maximum water storage elevation not in excess of fifteen acre-feet regardless of height is not considered a dam. This lower size limitation should be waived if there is a potentially significant downstream hazard. This definition applies whether the dam has a permanent reservoir or is a detention dam for temporary storage of floodwaters. The impounding capacity at maximum water storage elevation includes storage of floodwaters above the normal full storage elevation. Various types of dams include the following: a. Afterbay dam. See regulating dam.; b. Ambursen dam. A buttress dam in which the upstream part is a relatively thin flat slab usually made of reinforced concrete.; c. Arch dam. A concrete or masonry dam, which is curved upstream so as to transmit the major part of the water load to the abutments. d. Buttress dam. A dam consisting of a watertight part supported at intervals on the downstream side by a series of buttresses. A buttress dam can take many forms, such as a flat slab or a massive head buttress. e. Cofferdam. A temporary structure enclosing all or part of the construction area so that construction can proceed in the dry. A diversion cofferdam diverts a stream into a pipe, channel, tunnel, or other watercourse. f. Crib dam. A gravity dam built up of boxes, crossed timbers, or gabions filled with earth or rock. g. Diversion dam. A dam built to divert water from a waterway or stream into a different watercourse. h. Double curvature arch dam. An arch dam, which is curved vertically as well as horizontally. i. Earth dam. An embankment dam in which more than 50 percent of the total volume is formed of compacted earth material generally smaller than 3-inch size. j. Embankment dam. Any dam constructed of excavated natural materials or of industrial waste materials. k. Gravity dam. A dam constructed of concrete and/or masonry, which relies on its weight and internal strength for stability. l. Hollow gravity dam. A dam constructed of concrete and/or masonry on the outside but having a hollow interior and relying on its weight for stability. m. Hydraulic fill dam. An earth dam constructed of materials, often dredged, which are conveyed and placed by suspension in flowing water. n. Industrial waste dam. An embankment dam, usually built in stages, to create storage for the disposal of waste products from an industrial process. The waste products are conveyed as fine material suspended in water to the reservoir impounded by the embankment. The embankment may be built of conventional materials but sometimes incorporates suitable waste products. o. Masonry dam. Any dam constructed mainly of stone, brick, or concrete blocks jointed with mortar. A dam having only a masonry facing should not be referred to as a masonry dam. p. Mine tailings dam. An industrial waste dam in which the waste materials come from mining operations or mineral processing. q. Multiple arch dam. A buttress dam composed of a series of arches for the upstream face. r. Overflow dam. A dam designed to be overtopped. s. Regulating dam. A dam impounding a reservoir from which water is released to regulate the flow downstream. t. Rockfill dam. An embankment dam in which more than 50 percent of the total volume is composed of compacted or dumped cobbles, boulders, rock fragments, or quarried rock generally larger than 3-inch size. u. Roller-compacted concrete dam. A concrete gravity dam constructed by the use of a dry mix concrete transported by conventional construction equipment and compacted by rolling, usually with vibratory rollers. v. Rubble dam. A stone masonry dam in which the stones are unshaped or uncoursed. w. Saddle dam (or dike). A subsidiary dam of any type constructed across a saddle or low point on the perimeter of a reservoir. x. Tailings dam. See mine tailings dam.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Dam a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Dam" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=491" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Dam]" ;
skos:definition "An artificial barrier, including appurtenant works, constructed for the purpose of storage, control, or diversion of water, and which (1) is twenty-five feet or more in height from the natural bed of the stream or watercourse measured at the downstream toe of the barrier or from the lowest elevation of the outside limit of the barrier if it is not across a stream channel or watercourse, to the maximum water storage elevation or (2) has an impounding capacity at maximum water storage elevation of fifty acre-feet or more. Any such barrier which is under six feet in height regardless of storage capacity, or which has a storage capacity at maximum water storage elevation not in excess of fifteen acre-feet regardless of height is not considered a dam. This lower size limitation should be waived if there is a potentially significant downstream hazard. This definition applies whether the dam has a permanent reservoir or is a detention dam for temporary storage of floodwaters. The impounding capacity at maximum water storage elevation includes storage of floodwaters above the normal full storage elevation. Various types of dams include the following: a. Afterbay dam. See regulating dam.; b. Ambursen dam. A buttress dam in which the upstream part is a relatively thin flat slab usually made of reinforced concrete.; c. Arch dam. A concrete or masonry dam, which is curved upstream so as to transmit the major part of the water load to the abutments. d. Buttress dam. A dam consisting of a watertight part supported at intervals on the downstream side by a series of buttresses. A buttress dam can take many forms, such as a flat slab or a massive head buttress. e. Cofferdam. A temporary structure enclosing all or part of the construction area so that construction can proceed in the dry. A diversion cofferdam diverts a stream into a pipe, channel, tunnel, or other watercourse. f. Crib dam. A gravity dam built up of boxes, crossed timbers, or gabions filled with earth or rock. g. Diversion dam. A dam built to divert water from a waterway or stream into a different watercourse. h. Double curvature arch dam. An arch dam, which is curved vertically as well as horizontally. i. Earth dam. An embankment dam in which more than 50 percent of the total volume is formed of compacted earth material generally smaller than 3-inch size. j. Embankment dam. Any dam constructed of excavated natural materials or of industrial waste materials. k. Gravity dam. A dam constructed of concrete and/or masonry, which relies on its weight and internal strength for stability. l. Hollow gravity dam. A dam constructed of concrete and/or masonry on the outside but having a hollow interior and relying on its weight for stability. m. Hydraulic fill dam. An earth dam constructed of materials, often dredged, which are conveyed and placed by suspension in flowing water. n. Industrial waste dam. An embankment dam, usually built in stages, to create storage for the disposal of waste products from an industrial process. The waste products are conveyed as fine material suspended in water to the reservoir impounded by the embankment. The embankment may be built of conventional materials but sometimes incorporates suitable waste products. o. Masonry dam. Any dam constructed mainly of stone, brick, or concrete blocks jointed with mortar. A dam having only a masonry facing should not be referred to as a masonry dam. p. Mine tailings dam. An industrial waste dam in which the waste materials come from mining operations or mineral processing. q. Multiple arch dam. A buttress dam composed of a series of arches for the upstream face. r. Overflow dam. A dam designed to be overtopped. s. Regulating dam. A dam impounding a reservoir from which water is released to regulate the flow downstream. t. Rockfill dam. An embankment dam in which more than 50 percent of the total volume is composed of compacted or dumped cobbles, boulders, rock fragments, or quarried rock generally larger than 3-inch size. u. Roller-compacted concrete dam. A concrete gravity dam constructed by the use of a dry mix concrete transported by conventional construction equipment and compacted by rolling, usually with vibratory rollers. v. Rubble dam. A stone masonry dam in which the stones are unshaped or uncoursed. w. Saddle dam (or dike). A subsidiary dam of any type constructed across a saddle or low point on the perimeter of a reservoir. x. Tailings dam. See mine tailings dam." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Dam" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety is a leaf node.

Description

Dam safety is the art and science of ensuring the integrity and viability of dams such that they do not present unacceptable risks to the public, property, and the environment. It requires the collective application of engineering principles and experience, and a philosophy of risk management that recognizes that a dam is a structure whose safe functioning is not explicitly determined by its original design and construction. It also includes all actions taken to routinely monitor, evaluate, identify or predict dam safety issues and consequences related to failure including ensuring all reservoir regulation activities are performed in accordance with established water control plans in support of dam safety concerns. These actions are to be performed in concert with activities to document, publicize, and reduce, eliminate, or remediate, to the extent reasonably practicable, any unacceptable risks.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Dam Safety" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=493" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Dam Safety]" ;
skos:definition "Dam safety is the art and science of ensuring the integrity and viability of dams such that they do not present unacceptable risks to the public, property, and the environment. It requires the collective application of engineering principles and experience, and a philosophy of risk management that recognizes that a dam is a structure whose safe functioning is not explicitly determined by its original design and construction. It also includes all actions taken to routinely monitor, evaluate, identify or predict dam safety issues and consequences related to failure including ensuring all reservoir regulation activities are performed in accordance with established water control plans in support of dam safety concerns. These actions are to be performed in concert with activities to document, publicize, and reduce, eliminate, or remediate, to the extent reasonably practicable, any unacceptable risks." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Dam Safety" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Action_Classification_%28DSAC%29_System   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Action_Classification_%28DSAC%29_System

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Action_Classification_%28DSAC%29_System is a leaf node.

Description

The Dam Safety Action Classification system is intended to provide consistent and systematic guidelines for appropriate actions to address the dam safety issues and deficiencies of USACE dams. USACE dams are assigned a DSAC class informed by their incremental flood risk considered as a combination of probability of failure and potential life safety, economic, environmental, or other consequences. The DSAC table presents different levels and urgencies of actions that are commensurate with the different levels of incremental flood risk associated with USACE dams. These actions range from immediate recognition of a very high urgency requiring extraordinary and immediate action for dams considered critically near failure or dams with very high incremental flood risk through normal level of urgency for the operations and dam safety activities for dams with very low incremental flood risk and that meet all essential USACE guideline.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Action_Classification_%28DSAC%29_System a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Dam Safety Action Classification (DSAC) System" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=494" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Dam Safety Action Classification (DSAC) System]" ;
skos:altLabel "DSAC System" ;
skos:definition "The Dam Safety Action Classification system is intended to provide consistent and systematic guidelines for appropriate actions to address the dam safety issues and deficiencies of USACE dams. USACE dams are assigned a DSAC class informed by their incremental flood risk considered as a combination of probability of failure and potential life safety, economic, environmental, or other consequences. The DSAC table presents different levels and urgencies of actions that are commensurate with the different levels of incremental flood risk associated with USACE dams. These actions range from immediate recognition of a very high urgency requiring extraordinary and immediate action for dams considered critically near failure or dams with very high incremental flood risk through normal level of urgency for the operations and dam safety activities for dams with very low incremental flood risk and that meet all essential USACE guideline." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Dam Safety Action Classification (DSAC) System" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Committee   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Committee

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Committee is a leaf node.

Description

The Dam Safety Committee includes the Dam Safety Officer (DSO) and the Dam Safety Program Manager (DSPM) plus additional members as required. The members should include various technical engineering disciplines from within the district. Other disciplines and areas of expertise may be represented, as required by the DSO or Commander. There is a standing Dam Safety Committee at each level of the decentralized USACE program (districts, divisions, and HQ), who convening regularly to discuss dam safety project and program matters, and advice the Commander on critical dam safety related decisions.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=494" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Dam Safety Committee]" ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Deficiency   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Deficiency

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Deficiency is a leaf node.

Description

A material defect or load capacity limit that threatens a dam failure.

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Issue   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Issue

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Issue is a leaf node.

Description

Any confirmed or not yet confirmed condition at a dam that could result in intolerable life safety, economic, and environmental risks.

Implementation:

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Modification   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Modification

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Modification is a leaf node.

Description

A Dam Safety Modification is any planning, design, or construAction activity whose execution or improper execution could significantly impact the project's ability to operate as intended. The following activities will normally be considered dam safety modifications: all dam safety modification studies to bring projects within tolerable risks, all drilling and or grouting activities for a dam, replacement of hydraulic steel structures with new or significantly altered designs, installation of relief wells and collector systems, any drilling within or immediately adjacent to the dam, replacement of operating machinery other than like kind and similar activities. The following activities will normally be considered as routine and are not dam safety modifications: routine cleaning of drains, normal maintenance and repair of existing operating machinery, replacement of hydraulic steel structures and operating equipment with like kind components and similar routine activities performed by the district staff.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=494" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Dam Safety Modification]" ;

The following activities will normally be considered dam safety modifications: all dam safety modification studies to bring projects within tolerable risks, all drilling and or grouting activities for a dam, replacement of hydraulic steel structures with new or significantly altered designs, installation of relief wells and collector systems, any drilling within or immediately adjacent to the dam, replacement of operating machinery other than like kind and similar activities. The following activities will normally be considered as routine and are not dam safety modifications: routine cleaning of drains, normal maintenance and repair of existing operating machinery, replacement of hydraulic steel structures and operating equipment with like kind components and similar routine activities performed by the district staff." ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Modification_%28DSM%29_Lead_Engineer   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Modification_%28DSM%29_Lead_Engineer

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Modification_%28DSM%29_Lead_Engineer is a leaf node.

Description

The DSM lead engineer must be a senior level registered professional engineer (typically a civil, geotechnical, or structural engineer) or engineering geologist with extensive knowledge and skills related to the primary features associated with the project. The engineering geologist is required to be a registered professional engineer.Dam Safety Modification (DSM) Lead Engineer - The DSM lead engineer for all dam safety modification studies, designs, plans and specification, and engineering during construction must be assigned by the Director of the Dam Safety Production Center in consultation with the district DSO

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Modification_Risk_Assessment   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Modification_Risk_Assessment

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Modification_Risk_Assessment is a leaf node.

Description

The risk assessment addresses the life safety, economic, and environmental risks associated with the identified potential failure modes and the risk reduction that can be achieved with risk reduction measures, including potential staged implementation options.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Modification_Study   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Modification_Study

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Modification_Study is a leaf node.

Description

The safety case that presents the investigation, documentation, and rationale for modifications for dam safety at completed USACE projects. The report presents the formulation and evaluation for a full range of risk reduction alternatives with preliminary level cost estimates. A detailed risk assessment is required to look at incremental risk reduction alternatives that together meet the tolerable risk guidelines and cost effectiveness of reducing the risk to and below the minimum safety criteria. However, the level of detail should only be what is needed to justify the modification decision. Related NEPA (reference A.6) and ESA (reference A.10) studies will be conducted during the Modification Study, in support of the recommended risk reduction measures. The resultant Dam Safety Modification Decision Document will present a comparison of alternatives and the recommended risk management plan to include actions, components, risk reduction by increments or stages, implementation plan, detailed cost estimate, NEPA, and ESA determinations.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Modification_Study a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Dam Safety Modification Study" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=495" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Dam Safety Modification Study]" ;
skos:definition "The safety case that presents the investigation, documentation, and rationale for modifications for dam safety at completed USACE projects. The report presents the formulation and evaluation for a full range of risk reduction alternatives with preliminary level cost estimates. A detailed risk assessment is required to look at incremental risk reduction alternatives that together meet the tolerable risk guidelines and cost effectiveness of reducing the risk to and below the minimum safety criteria. However, the level of detail should only be what is needed to justify the modification decision. Related NEPA (reference A.6) and ESA (reference A.10) studies will be conducted during the Modification Study, in support of the recommended risk reduction measures. The resultant Dam Safety Modification Decision Document will present a comparison of alternatives and the recommended risk management plan to include actions, components, risk reduction by increments or stages, implementation plan, detailed cost estimate, NEPA, and ESA determinations." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Officer   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Officer

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Officer is a leaf node.

Description

A registered professional engineer with civil engineering background and with management abilities who is competent in the areas related to the design, construction, operation, inspection or evaluation of dams. They must understand adverse dam incidents and the potential causes and consequences of dam failure. The DSO is the highest-ranking Registered Professional Engineer in each level of USACE responsible for implementing the dam safety program of that organization. The Commander must ensure the DSO meets the technical qualifications and experience. The DSO is the Chair of the Dam Safety Committee.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Officer a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Dam Safety Officer" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=495" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Dam Safety Officer]" ;
skos:definition "A registered professional engineer with civil engineering background and with management abilities who is competent in the areas related to the design, construction, operation, inspection or evaluation of dams. The DSO is the highest-ranking Registered Professional Engineer in each level of USACE responsible for implementing the dam safety program of that organization. The Commander must ensure the DSO meets the technical qualifications and experience. The DSO is the Chair of the Dam Safety Committee." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Portfolio_Risk_Management   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Portfolio_Risk_Management

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Portfolio_Risk_Management is a leaf node.

Description

The management process shown generally on Figure 2.3 and for USACE in detail on Figure 3.1. It is a risk-informed USACE-wide portfolio perspective process applied to all features of all dams on a continuing basis. Dam Safety Program “ The purposes of a dam safety program are to protect life, property, and the environment by ensuring that all dams are designed, constructed, operated, and maintained as safely and effectively as is reasonably possible. Accomplishing these purposes require commitments to continually inspect, evaluate, and document the design, construction, operations, maintenance, rehabilitation, and emergency preparedness of each dam and the associated public. It also requires the archiving of documents on the inspections and history of dams and the training of personnel who inspect, evaluate, operate, and maintain them. Programs must instill an awareness of dams and the potential hazard that they may present in the owners, the users, the public, and the local and national decision-makers. On both local and national scales, program purposes also include periodic reporting on the degree of program implementation. Key to accomplishing these purposes is to attract, train, and retain a staff proficient in the art and science of dam design.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Portfolio_Risk_Management a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Dam Safety Portfolio Risk Management" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=496" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Dam Safety Portfolio Risk Management]" ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Program_Management_Tools   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Program_Management_Tools

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Program_Management_Tools is a leaf node.

Description

A shared software database, developed and maintained by USACE on behalf of FEMA, used for managing and monitoring Dam Safety Programs. It is used by multiple Federal and State agencies, to track program accomplishments, including entering data for the National Inventory of Dams and preparing the Federal Dam Safety Biennial Report to Congress.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Program_Manager_%28DSPM%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Program_Manager_%28DSPM%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Program_Manager_%28DSPM%29 is a leaf node.

Description

Dam Safety officials at the HQUSACE, MSC, and district level responsible for the overall daily management of the Dam Safety program. These managers normally support and report to the Dam Safety Officer at their respective level.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .

@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=496" ;
