Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Steering_Committee_%28DSSC%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Steering_Committee_%28DSSC%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Steering_Committee_%28DSSC%29 is a leaf node.

Description

A committee charged with facilitating and promoting dam safety as a fundamental USACE mission in all levels of the organization, promoting dam safety career development, disseminating pertinent information throughout USACE, and reviewing and evaluating policy, technical criteria and practices, administrative procedures, and regulatory functions to support the USACE dam safety program. The DSSC reviews experience and qualifications of dam safety staffing at all levels within the USACE to assess competency, serves as a resource for sharing information and project specific Lessons Learned, and makes recommendations for future research and development in areas related to dam safety. The team meets as required, and provides advice and information to the Special Assistant for Dam and Levee Safety.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Safety_Steering_Committee_%28DSSC%29 a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Dam Safety Steering Committee (DSSC)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=494" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Dam Safety Steering Committee (DSSC)]" ;
skos:altLabel "DSSC" ;
skos:definition "A committee charged with facilitating and promoting dam safety as a fundamental USACE mission in all levels of the organization, promoting dam safety career development, disseminating pertinent information throughout USACE, and reviewing and evaluating policy, technical criteria and practices, administrative procedures, and regulatory functions to support the USACE dam safety program. The DSSC reviews experience and qualifications of dam safety staffing at all levels within the USACE to assess competency, serves as a resource for sharing information and project specific Lessons Learned, and makes recommendations for future research and development in areas related to dam safety. The team meets as required, and provides advice and information to the Special Assistant for Dam and Levee Safety." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Dam Safety Steering Committee (DSSC)" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Senior_Oversight_Group_%28DSOG%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Senior_Oversight_Group_%28DSOG%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Senior_Oversight_Group_%28DSOG%29 is a leaf node.

Description

Designated USACE dam safety senior headquarters and field staff team that performs an oversight function for the Dam Safety program. The DSOG meets periodically to advise the Dam Safety Officer on key issues related to the program, such as determining Dam Safety Action Classifications. The DSOG generally consists of the following members: Special Assistant for Dam and Levee Safety (Chair); USACE CoP leaders (for Geotechnical, Structural and H&H technical disciplines); Regional representatives determined by Special Assistant for Dam and Levee Safety; USACE Business Line & Program Representatives to include USACE DSPM, Flood Damage Reduction, Navigation, Programs, and Risk Management Center Director; and any other Representatives determined by the Special Assistant for Dam and Levee Safety. The Senior Oversight Group is established to vet the findings of the Regional Risk Cadres and confirm dam safety work priorities based on portfolio risk findings.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_Senior_Oversight_Group_%28DSOG%29 a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Dam Senior Oversight Group (DSOG)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=496" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Dam Senior Oversight Group (DSOG)]" ;
skos:altLabel "DSOG" ;
skos:definition "Designated USACE dam safety senior headquarters and field staff team that performs an oversight function for the Dam Safety program. The DSOG meets periodically to advise the Dam Safety Officer on key issues related to the program, such as determining Dam Safety Action Classifications. The DSOG generally consists of the following members: Special Assistant for Dam and Levee Safety (Chair); USACE CoP leaders (for Geotechnical, Structural and H&H technical disciplines); Regional representatives determined by Special Assistant for Dam and Levee Safety; USACE Business Line & Program Representatives to include USACE DSPM, Flood Damage Reduction, Navigation, Programs, and Risk Management Center Director; and any other Representatives determined by the Special Assistant for Dam and Levee Safety. The Senior Oversight Group is established to vet the findings of the Regional Risk Cadres and confirm dam safety work priorities based on portfolio risk findings." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Dam Senior Oversight Group (DSOG)" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_failure   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_failure

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_failure is a leaf node.

Description

Failure characterized by the sudden, rapid, and uncontrolled release of impounded water. It is recognized that there are lesser degrees of failure and that any malfunction or abnormality outside the design assumptions and parameters that adversely affect a dam's primary function of impounding water is properly considered a failure. These lesser degrees of failure can lead to loss of services and progressively lead to or heighten the risk of a catastrophic failure.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_failure a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Dam failure" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=493" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Dam failure]" ;
skos:definition "Failure characterized by the sudden, rapid, and uncontrolled release of impounded water. It is recognized that there are lesser degrees of failure and that any malfunction or abnormality outside the design assumptions and parameters that adversely affect a dam's primary function of impounding water is properly considered a failure. These lesser degrees of failure can lead to loss of services and progressively lead to or heighten the risk of a catastrophic failure." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Dam failure" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_safety_preparedness   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_safety_preparedness

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dam_safety_preparedness is a leaf node.

Description

The quality or state of being prepared to deal with emergency conditions which endanger the structural integrity of the dam and/or downstream property and human life.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Dam safety preparedness]" ;
skos:definition "The quality or state of being prepared to deal with emergency conditions which endanger the structural integrity of the dam and/or downstream property and human life." ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Damming_Surface   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Damming_Surface

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Damming_Surface is a leaf node.

Description

Any surface of the structure that hold back water. In the case of a navigation lock, the damming surface could include the miter gates and lock walls. In the case of a hydropower unit, the damming surface could be the head gates on the penstocks

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=497" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Damming Surface]" ;
skos:definition "Any surface of the structure that hold back water. In the case of a navigation lock, the damming surface could include the miter gates and lock walls. In the case of a hydropower unit, the damming surface could be the head gates on the penstocks" ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Dead_storage   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Dead_storage

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Dead_storage is a leaf node.

Description

The storage that lies below the invert of the lowest outlet and that, therefore, cannot readily be withdrawn from the reservoir.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

Description

The maximum loading condition that the project was planned to withstand, although the project may fail at a lesser loading condition

The maximum water elevation including the flood surcharge that a dam is designed to withstand.

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Design_wind   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Design_wind

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Design_wind is a leaf node.

Description

The most severe wind that is reasonably possible at a particular reservoir for generating wind setup and run-up. The determination will generally include the results of meteorological studies, which combine wind velocity, duration, direction, and seasonal distribution characteristics in a realistic manner.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Design_wind a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Design wind" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=497" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Design wind]" ;
skos:definition "The most severe wind that is reasonably possible at a particular reservoir for generating wind setup and run-up. The determination will generally include the results of meteorological studies, which combine wind velocity, duration, direction, and seasonal distribution characteristics in a realistic manner." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Design wind" .

Description

A sheet, thin zone, or facing made of an impervious material such as concrete, steel, wood, or plastic. Also see core wall.

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Direct_Economic_Losses   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Direct_Economic_Losses

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Direct_Economic_Losses is a leaf node.

Description

Direct economic losses are the damage to property located downstream from the dam due to the failure. Items in this category include those commonly computed for the National Economic Development (NED) account in any USACE flood risk management study. These include damage to private and public buildings, contents of buildings, vehicles, public infrastructure such as roads and bridges, public utility infrastructure, agricultural crops, agricultural capital, and erosion losses to land.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Direct_Economic_Losses a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Direct Economic Losses" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=497" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Direct Economic Losses]" ;
skos:definition "Direct economic losses are the damage to property located downstream from the dam due to the failure. Items in this category include those commonly computed for the National Economic Development (NED) account in any USACE flood risk management study. These include damage to private and public buildings, contents of buildings, vehicles, public infrastructure such as roads and bridges, public utility infrastructure, agricultural crops, agricultural capital, and erosion losses to land." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Direct Economic Losses" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Diversion_channel,_canal,_or_tunnel   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Diversion_channel,_canal,_or_tunnel

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Diversion_channel,_canal,_or_tunnel is a leaf node.

Description

A waterway used to divert water from its natural course. The term is generally applied to a temporary arrangement, e.g., to by-pass water around a dam site during construction. Channel is normally used instead of canal when the waterway is short.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

<https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#Diversion_channel,_canal,_or_tunnel> a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Diversion channel, canal, or tunnel" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=497" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Diversion channel, canal, or tunnel]" ;
skos:definition "A waterway used to divert water from its natural course. The term is generally applied to a temporary arrangement, e.g., to by-pass water around a dam site during construction. Channel is normally used instead of canal when the waterway is short." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Diversion channel, canal, or tunnel" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Drain,_chimney   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Drain,_chimney

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Drain,_chimney is a leaf node.

Description

A vertical or inclined layer of pervious material in an embankment to facilitate and control drainage of the embankment fill.

Implementation:

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Drain,_toe   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Drain,_toe

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Drain,_toe is a leaf node.

Description

A system of pipe and/or pervious material along the downstream toe of a dam used to collect seepage from the foundation and embankment and convey it to a free outlet.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Drainage_curtain   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Drainage_curtain

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Drainage_curtain is a leaf node.

Description

Also called drainage wells or relief wells. A line of vertical wells or boreholes placed to facilitate drainage of the foundation and abutments and to reduce water pressure.

Implementation:

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Drawdown   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Drawdown

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Drawdown is a leaf node.

Description

The difference between a water level and a lower water level in a reservoir within a particular time. Used as a verb, it is the lowering of the water surface.

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Drum_gate   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Drum_gate

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Drum_gate is a leaf node.

Description

A type of spillway gate consisting of a long hollow drum. The drum may be held in its raised position by the water pressure in a flotation chamber beneath the dam.

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake is a leaf node.

Description

A sudden motion or trembling in the earth caused by the abrupt release of accumulated stress along a fault.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

rdfs:label "Earthquake" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=498" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Earthquake]" ;
skos:definition "A sudden motion or trembling in the earth caused by the abrupt release of accumulated stress along a fault." ;

skos:prefLabel "Earthquake" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_Maximum_Credible_%28MCE%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_Maximum_Credible_%28MCE%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_Maximum_Credible_%28MCE%29 is a leaf node.

Description

The MCE is defined as the greatest earthquake that can reasonably be expected to be generated by a specific source on the basis of seismological and geological evidence. Since a project site may be affected by earthquakes generated by various sources, each with its own fault mechanism, maximum earthquake magnitude, and distance from the site, multiple MCE's may be defined for the site, each with characteristic ground motion parameters and spectral shape. The MCE is determined by a DSHA and input from PSHA when site specific studies are performed.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

<https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#Earthquake,_Maximum_Credible_%28MCE%29> a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Earthquake, Maximum Credible (MCE)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=498" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Earthquake, Maximum Credible (MCE)]" ;
skos:altLabel "MCE" ;
skos:definition "The MCE is defined as the greatest earthquake that can reasonably be expected to be generated by a specific source on the basis of seismological and geological evidence. Since a project site may be affected by earthquakes generated by various sources, each with its own fault mechanism, maximum earthquake magnitude, and distance from the site, multiple MCE's may be defined for the site, each with characteristic ground motion parameters and spectral shape. The MCE is determined by a DSHA and input from PSHA when site specific studies are performed." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Earthquake, Maximum Credible (MCE)" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_Maximum_Design_%28MDE%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_Maximum_Design_%28MDE%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_Maximum_Design_%28MDE%29 is a leaf node.

Description

The MDE is the maximum level of ground motion for which a structure is designed or evaluated. The associated performance requirement is that the project performs without catastrophic failure, such as uncontrolled release of a reservoir, although severe damage or economic loss may be tolerated. For critical features, the MDE is the same as the MCE. For all other features, the MDE must be selected as a minimum of event with a 10% probability of exceedance in 100 years. ( This corresponds to an average return period of 975 years). The longer or shorter return period for the non critical features can be use if warranted. The MDE can be characterized as a deterministic or probabilistic event.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

<https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#Earthquake,_Maximum_Design_%28MDE%29> a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Earthquake, Maximum Design (MDE)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=499" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Earthquake, Maximum Design (MDE)]" ;
skos:altLabel "MDE" ;
skos:definition "The MDE is the maximum level of ground motion for which a structure is designed or evaluated. The associated performance requirement is that the project performs without catastrophic failure, such as uncontrolled release of a reservoir, although severe damage or economic loss may be tolerated. For critical features, the MDE is the same as the MCE. For all other features, the MDE must be selected as a minimum of event with a 10% probability of exceedance in 100 years. ( This corresponds to an average return period of 975 years). The longer or shorter return period for the non critical features can be use if warranted. The MDE can be characterized as a deterministic or probabilistic event." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Earthquake, Maximum Design (MDE)" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_Operating_Basis_%28OBE%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_Operating_Basis_%28OBE%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_Operating_Basis_%28OBE%29 is a leaf node.

Description

The OBE is considered to be an earthquake that has a 50 percent chance of being exceeded in 100 years (or a 144-year return period).

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

<https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#Earthquake,_Operating_Basis_%28OBE%29> a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Earthquake, Operating Basis (OBE)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=499" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Earthquake, Operating Basis (OBE)]" ;
skos:altLabel "OBE" ;

skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Earthquake, Operating Basis (OBE)" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_Safety_Evaluation_%28SEE%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_Safety_Evaluation_%28SEE%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_Safety_Evaluation_%28SEE%29 is a leaf node.

Description

The earthquake, expressed in terms of magnitude and closest distance from the dam site or in terms of the characteristics of the time history of free-field ground motions, for which the safety of the dam and critical structures associated with the dam are to be evaluated. In many cases, this earthquake will be the maximum credible earthquake to which the dam will be exposed. However, in other cases where the possible sources of ground motion are not easily apparent, it may be a motion with prescribed characteristics selected on the basis of a probabilistic assessment of the ground motions that may occur in the vicinity of the dam. To be considered safe, it should be demonstrated that the dam can withstand this level of earthquake shaking without release of water from the reservoir.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

<https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#Earthquake,_Safety_Evaluation_%28SEE%29> a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Earthquake, Safety Evaluation (SEE)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=499" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Earthquake, Safety Evaluation (SEE)]" ;
skos:altLabel "SEE" ;
skos:definition "The earthquake, expressed in terms of magnitude and closest distance from the dam site or in terms of the characteristics of the time history of free-field ground motions, for which the safety of the dam and critical structures associated with the dam are to be evaluated. In many cases, this earthquake will be the maximum credible earthquake to which the dam will be exposed. However, in other cases where the possible sources of ground motion are not easily apparent, it may be a motion with prescribed characteristics selected on the basis of a probabilistic assessment of the ground motions that may occur in the vicinity of the dam. To be considered safe, it should be demonstrated that the dam can withstand this level of earthquake shaking without release of water from the reservoir." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Earthquake, Safety Evaluation (SEE)" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_synthetic   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_synthetic

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Earthquake,_synthetic is a leaf node.

Description

Earthquake time history records developed from mathematical models that use white noise, filtered white noise, and stationary and non-stationary filtered white noise, or theoretical seismic source models of failure in the fault zone. (White noise is random energy containing all frequency components in equal proportions. Stationary white noise is random energy with statistical characteristics that do not vary with time).

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

<https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#Earthquake,_synthetic> a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Earthquake, synthetic" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=499" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Earthquake, synthetic]" ;
skos:definition "Earthquake time history records developed from mathematical models that use white noise, filtered white noise, and stationary and non-stationary filtered white noise, or theoretical seismic source models of failure in the fault zone. (White noise is random energy containing all frequency components in equal proportions. Stationary white noise is random energy with statistical characteristics that do not vary with time)." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Earthquake, synthetic" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Economic_Consequences   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Economic_Consequences

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Economic_Consequences is a leaf node.

Description

Direct and indirect losses of the failure of a dam and other economic impacts on the regional or national economy. Part of the direct losses is the damage to property located downstream from the dam due to the failure. Items in this category include those commonly computed for the National Economic Development (NED) account in any USACE flood risk management study.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Economic_Damages   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Economic_Damages

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Economic_Damages is a leaf node.

Description

These include damage to private and public buildings, contents of buildings, vehicles, public infrastructure such as roads and bridges, public utility infrastructure, agricultural crops, agricultural capital, and erosion losses to land.

Implementation:

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Economic_Regret   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Economic_Regret

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Economic_Regret is a leaf node.

Description

Condition when the costs of making a wrong decision are deemed to be high. The basic concept of regret is the difference between the outcome of the "best alternative for a future, uncertain state" and outcome of each alternative evaluated for that state. So it is really the potential costs, if you choose an alternative as the best given some future scenario, and a different future actually happens. All regret values are determined by comparing each alternative to the best (e.g. maximum net benefits) for a scenario. So you end up with a regret matrix with scenarios as column headings and alternatives as row headings. There is nothing in the notion about regret about it being "too high." The minimax principle is usually applied to regret to identify the plan or plans that are robust across multiple future scenarios.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Economic_Regret a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Economic Regret" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=499" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Economic Regret]" ;
skos:definition "Condition when the costs of making a wrong decision are deemed to be high. The basic concept of regret is the difference between the outcome of the \"best alternative for a future, uncertain state\" and outcome of each alternative evaluated for that state. So it is really the potential costs, if you choose an alternative as the best given some future scenario, and a different future actually happens. All regret values are determined by comparing each alternative to the best (e.g. maximum net benefits) for a scenario. So you end up with a regret matrix with scenarios as column headings and alternatives as row headings. There is nothing in the notion about regret about it being \"too high.\" The minimax principle is usually applied to regret to identify the plan or plans that are robust across multiple future scenarios." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Economic Regret" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Efficiency   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Efficiency

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Efficiency is a leaf node.

Description

Efficiency is the need for society to distribute and use available resources so as to achieve the greatest benefit. For dam safety investments, this means ensuring that resources and expenditure directed to safety improvements are cost-effective and that an appropriate balance between the monetary and non-monetary benefits and the monetary and non-monetary costs is achieved.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Efficiency a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Efficiency" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=500" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Efficiency]" ;
skos:definition "Efficiency is the need for society to distribute and use available resources so as to achieve the greatest benefit. For dam safety investments, this means ensuring that resources and expenditure directed to safety improvements are cost-effective and that an appropriate balance between the monetary and non-monetary benefits and the monetary and non-monetary costs is achieved." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Embankment   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Embankment

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Embankment is a leaf node.

Description

A raised structure of earth, rocks, or gravel, usually intended to retain water or carry a roadway.

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency is a leaf node.

Description

An emergency, in terms of dam operation, is a condition, which develops unexpectedly, endangers the structural integrity of the dam and/or downstream property and human life, and requires immediate action.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Emergency" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=500" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Emergency]" ;
skos:definition "An emergency, in terms of dam operation, is a condition, which develops unexpectedly, endangers the structural integrity of the dam and/or downstream property and human life, and requires immediate action." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Emergency" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency_Action_Plan_%28EAP%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency_Action_Plan_%28EAP%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency_Action_Plan_%28EAP%29 is a leaf node.

Description

An action plan that provides detailed instructions for agencies and individuals for responding to emergencies such as a potential dam failure. Plans typically include threat recognition, emergency action message formulation, message dissemination to authorities and the public, provisions for search and rescue, and early stages of recovery.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency_Action_Plan_%28EAP%29 a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Emergency Action Plan (EAP)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=500" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Emergency Action Plan (EAP)]" ;
skos:altLabel "EAP" ;
skos:definition "An action plan that provides detailed instructions for agencies and individuals for responding to emergencies such as a potential dam failure. Plans typically include threat recognition, emergency action message formulation, message dissemination to authorities and the public, provisions for search and rescue, and early stages of recovery." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Emergency Action Plan (EAP)" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency_Exercise   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency_Exercise

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency_Exercise is a leaf node.

Description

Full Scale “ The full scale exercise is the most complex level of exercise. It evaluates the operational capability of all facets of the emergency management system (both dam operator and state and local emergency management agencies) interactively in a stressful environment with the actual mobilization of personnel and resources. It includes deployment to and movement in the field of personnel and equipment to demonstrate coordination and response capability. The participants actively "play out" their roles in a dynamic environment that provides the highest degree of realism possible for the simulated event. Actual evacuation of critical residents may be exercised if previously announced to the public. - Drill “ A drill is the lowest level exercise that involves an actual exercise. It tests, develops, or maintains skills in a single emergency response procedure. An example of a drill is an in-house exercise performed to verify the validity of telephone numbers and other means of communication along with the response of the entity responsible for the dam. A drill is considered a necessary part of ongoing training. - Functional “ The functional exercise is the highest level exercise that does not involve the full activation of the entity responsible for dam operation and state and local emergency management agency field personnel and facilities or test evacuation of residents downstream of the dam. It involves the various levels of the entity responsible for dam operation and state and local emergency management personnel that would be involved in an actual emergency. The functional exercise takes place in a stress-induced environment with time constraints and involves the simulation of a dam failure and other specified events. The participants "act out" their actual roles. The exercise is designed to evaluate both the internal capabilities and responses of the entity responsible for dam operation and the workability of the information in the EAP used by the emergency management officials to carry out their responsibilities. The functional exercise also is designed to evaluate the coordination activities between the entity responsible for dam operation and emergency management personnel. - Orientation Seminar “ This exercise is a seminar that involves bringing together those with a role or interest in an EAP, i.e., entity responsible for dam operation and state and local emergency management agencies, to discuss the EAP and initial plans for an annual drill or more in-depth comprehensive exercise. The seminar does not involve an actual exercise of the EAP. Instead, it is a meeting that enables each participant to become familiar with the EAP and the roles, responsibilities, and procedures of those involved. An orientation seminar can also be used to discuss and describe technical matters with involved, non-technical personnel. - Tabletop “ The tabletop exercise involves a meeting of the entity responsible for dam operation and the state and local emergency management officials in a conference room environment. The format is usually informal with minimum stress involved. The exercise begins with the description of a simulated event and proceeds with discussions by the participants to evaluate the EAP and response procedures and to resolve concerns regarding coordination and responsibilities.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency_Exercise a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Emergency Exercise" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=500",
"https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=501" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Emergency Exercise]" ;
skos:definition "Drill “ A drill is the lowest level exercise that involves an actual exercise. It tests, develops, or maintains skills in a single emergency response procedure. An example of a drill is an in-house exercise performed to verify the validity of telephone numbers and other means of communication along with the response of the entity responsible for the dam. A drill is considered a necessary part of ongoing training.",
"Full Scale “ The full scale exercise is the most complex level of exercise. It evaluates the operational capability of all facets of the emergency management system (both dam operator and state and local emergency management agencies) interactively in a stressful environment with the actual mobilization of personnel and resources. It includes deployment to and movement in the field of personnel and equipment to demonstrate coordination and response capability. The participants actively \"play out\" their roles in a dynamic environment that provides the highest degree of realism possible for the simulated event. Actual evacuation of critical residents may be exercised if previously announced to the public.",
"Functional “ The functional exercise is the highest level exercise that does not involve the full activation of the entity responsible for dam operation and state and local emergency management agency field personnel and facilities or test evacuation of residents downstream of the dam. It involves the various levels of the entity responsible for dam operation and state and local emergency management personnel that would be involved in an actual emergency. The functional exercise takes place in a stress-induced environment with time constraints and involves the simulation of a dam failure and other specified events. The participants \"act out\" their actual roles. The exercise is designed to evaluate both the internal capabilities and responses of the entity responsible for dam operation and the workability of the information in the EAP used by the emergency management officials to carry out their responsibilities. The functional exercise also is designed to evaluate the coordination activities between the entity responsible for dam operation and emergency management personnel.",
"Orientation Seminar “ This exercise is a seminar that involves bringing together those with a role or interest in an EAP, i.e., entity responsible for dam operation and state and local emergency management agencies, to discuss the EAP and initial plans for an annual drill or more in-depth comprehensive exercise. The seminar does not involve an actual exercise of the EAP. Instead, it is a meeting that enables each participant to become familiar with the EAP and the roles, responsibilities, and procedures of those involved. An orientation seminar can also be used to discuss and describe technical matters with involved, non-technical personnel.",
"Tabletop “ The tabletop exercise involves a meeting of the entity responsible for dam operation and the state and local emergency management officials in a conference room environment. The format is usually informal with minimum stress involved. The exercise begins with the description of a simulated event and proceeds with discussions by the participants to evaluate the EAP and response procedures and to resolve concerns regarding coordination and responsibilities." ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency_gate   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency_gate

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Emergency_gate is a leaf node.

Description

A standby or auxiliary gate used when the normal means of water control is not available. Sometimes referred to as guard gate.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Endangered_Species_Act_%28ESA%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Endangered_Species_Act_%28ESA%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Endangered_Species_Act_%28ESA%29 is a leaf node.

Description

The Endangered Species Act of 1973 (7 U.S.C. Â§ 136, 16 U.S.C. Â§ 1531 et seq.) or ESA is the most wide-ranging of the dozens of United States environmental laws passed in the 1970s (references A.6, A.9, and A.10). As stated in section 2 of the act, it was designed to protect critically imperiled species from extinction as a "consequence of economic growth and development untendered by adequate concern and conservation." See ER 1105-2-100 Appendix C (reference A.39) for detailed discussion.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Endangered_Species_Act_%28ESA%29 a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Endangered Species Act (ESA)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=501" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Endangered Species Act (ESA)]" ;
skos:altLabel "ESA" ;
skos:definition "The Endangered Species Act of 1973 (7 U.S.C. Â§ 136, 16 U.S.C. Â§ 1531 et seq.) or ESA is the most wide-ranging of the dozens of United States environmental laws passed in the 1970s (references A.6, A.9, and A.10). As stated in section 2 of the act, it was designed to protect critically imperiled species from extinction as a \"consequence of economic growth and development untendered by adequate concern and conservation.\" See ER 1105-2-100 Appendix C (reference A.39) for detailed discussion." ;

Description

A device constructed in a waterway to reduce the kinetic energy of fast flowing water.

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Environmental_Impact_Statement_%28EIS%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Environmental_Impact_Statement_%28EIS%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Environmental_Impact_Statement_%28EIS%29 is a leaf node.

Description

An environmental impact statement, in the United States, is a document that must be filed when the federal government takes a "major Federal action significantly affecting the quality of the human environment." The law requiring this is the National Environmental Policy Act. See ER 200-2-2 (reference A.34) and ER 1105-2-100, Appendix C (reference A.39), for details on preparation of EIS.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Environmental_Impact_Statement_%28EIS%29 a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Environmental Impact Statement (EIS)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=502" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Environmental Impact Statement (EIS)]" ;
skos:altLabel "EIS" ;
skos:definition "An environmental impact statement, in the United States, is a document that must be filed when the federal government takes a \"major Federal action significantly affecting the quality of the human environment.\" The law requiring this is the National Environmental Policy Act. See ER 200-2-2 (reference A.34) and ER 1105-2-100, Appendix C (reference A.39), for details on preparation of EIS." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Environmental_and_other_Non-monetary_Consequences   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Environmental_and_other_Non-monetary_Consequences

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Environmental_and_other_Non-monetary_Consequences is a leaf node.

Description

Direct and indirect consequences that cannot be measured in monetary terms. These stem from the impacts of the dam failure flood and loss of pool on environmental, cultural, and historic resources. In most cases, the assessment of the impacts of dam failure will be the reporting of area and type of habitat impacted, habitat of threatened and endangered species impacted, number and type of historic sites and the cultural significance areas impacted. An indirect non-monetary consequence could be the exposure of people and the ecosystem to hazardous and toxic material released from landfills, warehouses, and other facilities. An estimate of the locations and quantities should be compiled identifying where significant quantities are concentrated.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Environmental_and_other_Non-monetary_Consequences a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Environmental and other Non-monetary Consequences" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=501" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Environmental and other Non-monetary Consequences]" ;
skos:definition "Direct and indirect consequences that cannot be measured in monetary terms. These stem from the impacts of the dam failure flood and loss of pool on environmental, cultural, and historic resources. In most cases, the assessment of the impacts of dam failure will be the reporting of area and type of habitat impacted, habitat of threatened and endangered species impacted, number and type of historic sites and the cultural significance areas impacted. An indirect non-monetary consequence could be the exposure of people and the ecosystem to hazardous and toxic material released from landfills, warehouses, and other facilities. An estimate of the locations and quantities should be compiled identifying where significant quantities are concentrated." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Environmental and other Non-monetary Consequences" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Epicenter   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Epicenter

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Epicenter is a leaf node.

Description

The point on the earth's surface located vertically above the point of origin of an earthquake.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Epicenter a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Epicenter" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=502" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Epicenter]" ;
skos:definition "The point on the earth's surface located vertically above the point of origin of an earthquake." ;

skos:prefLabel "Epicenter" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Equity_in_Risk_Management   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Equity_in_Risk_Management

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Equity_in_Risk_Management is a leaf node.

Description

Equity, in the risk management context, is the right of individuals and society to be protected, and the right that the interests of all are treated with fairness, placing all members of society on a (more) equal footing in terms of levels of risk faced. The equity objective is addressed by requiring that all risks higher than a limit value be brought down below the limit, except in extraordinary circumstances.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Equity_in_Risk_Management a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Equity in Risk Management" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=502" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Equity in Risk Management]" ;
skos:definition "Equity, in the risk management context, is the right of individuals and society to be protected, and the right that the interests of all are treated with fairness, placing all members of society on a (more) equal footing in terms of levels of risk faced. The equity objective is addressed by requiring that all risks higher than a limit value be brought down below the limit, except in extraordinary circumstances." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Equity in Risk Management" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Essential_Agency_Guidelines   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Essential_Agency_Guidelines

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Essential_Agency_Guidelines is a leaf node.

Description

The state-of-practice for design, construction, operation, and maintenance of USACE dams as documented in current USACE regulations. The requirements specified in these USACE regulations must be met for a dam to achieve DSAC 5 (Normal) classification status. These regulations include: Engineer Circulars, Engineer Regulations, Engineer Manuals, Engineer Pamphlets and Engineer Technical Letters; and Engineering and Construction Bulletins, and other official HQUSACE dam safety-related Policy Letters and guidance. Current state-of-practice guidance is summarized in Appendix F.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Essential_Agency_Guidelines a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Essential Agency Guidelines" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=502" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Essential Agency Guidelines]" ;
skos:definition "The state-of-practice for design, construction, operation, and maintenance of USACE dams as documented in current USACE regulations. The requirements specified in these USACE regulations must be met for a dam to achieve DSAC 5 (Normal) classification status. These regulations include: Engineer Circulars, Engineer Regulations, Engineer Manuals, Engineer Pamphlets and Engineer Technical Letters; and Engineering and Construction Bulletins, and other official HQUSACE dam safety-related Policy Letters and guidance. Current state-of-practice guidance is summarized in Appendix F." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Essential Agency Guidelines" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Event_Tree%28s%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Event_Tree%28s%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Event_Tree%28s%29 is a leaf node.

Description

An event tree serves as a model of the physical dam system in which each node represents an identifiable behavior of the dam or its physical components and each event should be something that happens in space or time (Hartford and Baecher, 2004). An event tree begins with a single initiating branch on the left hand side and progress toward more detailed events to the right hand side. Starting with an initiating event branch (e.g. a severe flood, an earthquake or other natural or human caused hazards), each node is divided at various nodes to generate all possible subsequent events. Each node is an origin of possible subsequent events and each branch is a possible event that is a logical consequence of the one before it, and a necessary precursor of the one that follows. As the number of events increases, structure fans outs like the branches of a tree until each event tree chain comes to a terminal branch. Terminal branches are the system outcome or system effect of an initiating event which leads to adverse consequences or failure of the system completely or partially. The tree may be extended to represent the economic damages and life loss consequences associated with the terminal branches.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Event_Tree%28s%29 a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Event Tree(s)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=502" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Event Tree(s)]" ;
skos:definition "An event tree serves as a model of the physical dam system in which each node represents an identifiable behavior of the dam or its physical components and each event should be something that happens in space or time (Hartford and Baecher, 2004). An event tree begins with a single initiating branch on the left hand side and progress toward more detailed events to the right hand side. Starting with an initiating event branch (e.g. a severe flood, an earthquake or other natural or human caused hazards), each node is divided at various nodes to generate all possible subsequent events. Each node is an origin of possible subsequent events and each branch is a possible event that is a logical consequence of the one before it, and a necessary precursor of the one that follows. As the number of events increases, structure fans outs like the branches of a tree until each event tree chain comes to a terminal branch. Terminal branches are the system outcome or system effect of an initiating event which leads to adverse consequences or failure of the system completely or partially. The tree may be extended to represent the economic damages and life loss consequences associated with the terminal branches." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Event Tree(s)" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Exposure_Assessment   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Exposure_Assessment

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Exposure_Assessment is a leaf node.

Description

Exposure occurs when a susceptible asset comes in contact with a hazard. An exposure assessment, then, is the determination or estimation (which may be qualitative or quantitative) of the magnitude, frequency, or duration, and route of exposure.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Exposure_Assessment a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Exposure Assessment" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=503" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Exposure Assessment]" ;
skos:definition "Exposure occurs when a susceptible asset comes in contact with a hazard. An exposure assessment, then, is the determination or estimation (which may be qualitative or quantitative) of the magnitude, frequency, or duration, and route of exposure." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Exposure Assessment" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:F-N_chart   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:F-N_chart

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:F-N_chart is a leaf node.

Description

This chart is a plot of the annual probability of exceedance (greater than or equal to) of potential life loss (F) vs. incremental potential loss of life (N) due to failure compared to the no failure condition. Thus, the F-N chart displays the entire estimated probability distribution of life loss for a reservoir encompassing all failure modes and all population exposure scenarios for a particular reservoir. See figure 5.4.b.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:F-N_chart a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "F-N chart" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=505" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[F-N chart]" ;
skos:altLabel "Plot" ;
skos:definition "This chart is a plot of the annual probability of exceedance (greater than or equal to) of potential life loss (F) vs. incremental potential loss of life (N) due to failure compared to the no failure condition. Thus, the F-N chart displays the entire estimated probability distribution of life loss for a reservoir encompassing all failure modes and all population exposure scenarios for a particular reservoir. See figure 5.4.b." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Failure_Mode   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Failure_Mode

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Failure_Mode is a leaf node.

Description

A way that failure can occur, described by the means by which element or component failures must occur to cause loss of the sub-system or system function of a dam that could result in failure.

Implementation:

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Failure_of_a_Water_Control_System   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Failure_of_a_Water_Control_System

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Failure_of_a_Water_Control_System is a leaf node.

Description

A water control system failure is any condition that results in the uncontrolled release or discharge of water. This might include misoperation involving improper or unintended opening or closing of gates, valves, operation of pumps, etc. Misoperation leading to systems not operating when needed or intended (i.e. gates fail to open on demand) might also lead to failure. Another example could be structural failure involving partial or total collapse of a gate.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Failure_of_a_Water_Control_System a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Failure of a Water Control System" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=503" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Failure of a Water Control System]" ;
skos:definition "A water control system failure is any condition that results in the uncontrolled release or discharge of water. This might include misoperation involving improper or unintended opening or closing of gates, valves, operation of pumps, etc. Misoperation leading to systems not operating when needed or intended (i.e. gates fail to open on demand) might also lead to failure. Another example could be structural failure involving partial or total collapse of a gate." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Failure of a Water Control System" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Fault   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Fault

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Fault is a leaf node.

Description

A fracture or fracture zone in the earth crust along which there has been displacement of the two sides relative to one another.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Fault]" ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Fault,_active   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Fault,_active

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Fault,_active is a leaf node.

Description

A fault which, because of its present tectonic setting, can undergo movement from time to time in the immediate geologic future.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .

@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

<https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#Fault,_active> a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Fault, active" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=503" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Fault, active]" ;

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Fault,_capable   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Fault,_capable

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Fault,_capable is a leaf node.

Description

An active fault that is judged capable of producing macro earthquakes and exhibits one or more of the following characteristics: years. a. Movement at or near the ground surface at least once within the past 35,000 b. Macroseismicity (3.5 magnitude Richter or greater) instrumentally determined with records of sufficient precision to demonstrate a direct relationship with the fault. c. A structural relationship to a capable fault such that movement on one fault could be reasonably expected to cause movement on the other. d. Established patterns of microseismicity, which define a fault, with historic macroseismicity that can reasonably, be associated with the fault.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

<https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#Fault,_capable> a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Fault, capable" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=503" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Fault, capable]" ;
skos:definition "An active fault that is judged capable of producing macro earthquakes and exhibits one or more of the following characteristics: years. a. Movement at or near the ground surface at least once within the past 35,000 b. Macroseismicity (3.5 magnitude Richter or greater) instrumentally determined with records of sufficient precision to demonstrate a direct relationship with the fault. c. A structural relationship to a capable fault such that movement on one fault could be reasonably expected to cause movement on the other. d. Established patterns of microseismicity, which define a fault, with historic macroseismicity that can reasonably, be associated with the fault." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Fault, capable" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Fetch   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Fetch

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Fetch is a leaf node.

Description

The straight-line distance across a body of water subject to wind forces. The fetch is one of the factors used in calculating wave heights in a reservoir.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Fetch a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Fetch" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=504" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Fetch]" ;
skos:definition "The straight-line distance across a body of water subject to wind forces. The fetch is one of the factors used in calculating wave heights in a reservoir." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Fetch" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Filter_%28filter_zone%29   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Filter_%28filter_zone%29

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Filter_%28filter_zone%29 is a leaf node.

Description

One or more layers of granular material graded (either naturally or by selection) so as to allow seepage through or within the layers while preventing the migration of material from adjacent zones.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Filter_%28filter_zone%29 a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Filter (filter zone)" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=504" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Filter (filter zone)]" ;
skos:definition "One or more layers of granular material graded (either naturally or by selection) so as to allow seepage through or within the layers while preventing the migration of material from adjacent zones." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Filter (filter zone)" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Fixed_wheel_gate   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Fixed_wheel_gate

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Fixed_wheel_gate is a leaf node.

Description

A gate having wheels or rollers mounted on the end posts of the gate. The wheels bear against rails fixed in side grooves or gate guides.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Fixed_wheel_gate a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Fixed wheel gate" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=506" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Fixed wheel gate]" ;
skos:altLabel "fixed axle gate",
"fixed roller gate" ;
skos:definition "A gate having wheels or rollers mounted on the end posts of the gate. The wheels bear against rails fixed in side grooves or gate guides." ;
skos:inScheme ER-1110-2-1156: ;
skos:prefLabel "Fixed wheel gate" .

Concept: ER-1110-2-1156:Flap_gate   back to top

  • skos:Concept
    • ER-1110-2-1156:Flap_gate

NOTE ER-1110-2-1156:Flap_gate is a leaf node.

Description

A gate hinged along one edge, usually either the top or bottom edge. Examples of bottom-hinged flap gates are tilting gates and fish belly gates so called from their shape in cross section.

Implementation:

@prefix ER-1110-2-1156: <https://usace-data.com/civil-works/glossary/ER-1110-2-1156#> .
@prefix dcterms: <http://purl.org/dc/terms/> .
@prefix pav: <http://purl.org/pav#> .
@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .
@prefix skos: <http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#> .
@prefix wov: <http://www.knowledgesmarts.com/ontologies/wov#> .

ER-1110-2-1156:Flap_gate a wov:GlossaryTerm,
skos:Concept ;
rdfs:label "Flap gate" ;
dcterms:bibliographicCitation "https://www.publications.usace.army.mil/Portals/76/Users/182/86/2486/er_1110-2-1156.pdf#page=506" ;
pav:wasDerivedFrom "glossaries/CivilWorks/ER-1110-2-1156.yaml#term[Flap gate]" ;
skos:definition "A gate hinged along one edge, usually either the top or bottom edge. Examples of bottom-hinged flap gates are tilting gates and fish belly gates so called from their shape in cross section." ;
